WRITING.TEXT: I'm working my way through all of his videos from the beginning and noticed it changed over to 1M subscribers. Awesome accomplishment and well deserved.

I honestly never thought I'd make it to my 30's, hell, I didn't think I'd live to graduate high school. I've been suicidal since elementary school. 20+ years later, the only thing that changed is now I actually know how to do it whereas in elementary, though I tried, those attempts were, well, childish. I cannot imagine another 5+ years of this, let alone 50. PTSD and depression win. I want out. Only thing keeping me here at the moment is my cat. His previous owners dumped him at the shelter after having him for a decade. Who does that? I won't let him be thrown away like that because of me. But he's old, and when he dies, well, what's keeping me here?
Definitely painless. And I'm terrified to fail because I've seen what can happen physically depending on the method used. It would have to be 100%. Unfortunately not many things are 100%.

Childhood sucked. All kinds of abuse. Apparently I shouldn't have talked about killing myself because it "scares people" which is more important than my actually wanting to kill myself. The self injury was "just a phase" the eating disorder "wasn't severe enough" even though a specialist had me hospitalized and said I should have been a lot sooner. I'm an expert at faking being "normal" whatever that is. Or at least not seeming as fucked up as I am. No one has ever taken me seriously anyway. Maybe if they would have I wouldn't be this way. That's neither here nor there though.

I've had the same thoughts. You are definitely not alone. Unfortunately COVID didn't kill me. I even made myself a Do Not Intubate when I was hospitalized. It was amusing to me. I'm on medications for severe depression and suicidality and they basically ask if I want my life to be saved. Strange world we live in.
This should be submitted to a photo contest of some kind. Awesome shot!

* #8220;Just this side of heaven is a place called Rainbow Bridge.* *When an animal dies that has been especially close to someone here, that pet goes to Rainbow Bridge. There are meadows and hills for all of our special friends so they can run and play together. There is plenty of food, water* and *sunshine, and our friends are warm and comfortable.* *All the animals who had been ill and old are restored to health and vigor. Those who were hurt or maimed are made whole and strong again, just as we remember them in our dreams of days and times gone by. The animals are happy and content, except for one small thing; they each miss someone very special to them, who had to be left behind.* *They all run and play together, but the day comes when one suddenly stops and looks into the distance. His bright eyes are intent. His eager body quivers. Suddenly he begins to run from the group, flying over the green grass, his legs carrying him faster and faster.* *You have been spotted, and when you and your special friend finally meet, you cling together in joyous reunion, never to be parted again. The happy kisses rain upon your face; your hands again caress the beloved head, and you look once more into the trusting eyes of your pet, so long gone from your life but never absent from your heart.* *Then you cross Rainbow Bridge together #8230;. #8221;* #8212; Author unknown
There is nothing wrong with being sad when something dies. It's 100% normal. I would in no way consider this your "fault." There are many, MANY reasons that the duckling may not have not made it.

WRITING.TITLE: Side Effect Question
WRITING.TEXT: I don't know if this is allowed. I read the rules and didn't see anything stating it wasn't. Anywho, I'm on lithium for suicidality. It's caused me to gain 40 lbs. I'm short, only 5'1, and have a history of anorexia. It's been a mindfuck. I'm currently "obese" by BMI charts, which I know mean nothing but having "obesity" on my medical record is again, a mindfuck. We've tried lowering the dose to see if I could lose some weight, but it didn't work. Any lower and I needed to go back up because I was not coping well. Even when I restrict my intake (hello anorexia) I still don't lose much, if any, weight. So my question is has anyone managed to either lose the weight or just gotten in better shape? Right now I'm all flabby and I used to be known for being fit and in shape. I don't know the person staring back at me in the mirror anymore. :(

I'm slowly getting back in to working out. I'm still recovering from pneumonia so it's a very slow process. I definitely miss lifting weights and am so weak it's kind of discouraging. But yes, exercise was definitely what saved my life through undergrad. It was just impossible when the depression was as bad as it was. Side effects do suck. It's not like I can explain it to people when they tell me how fat I've gotten. "Yeah I'm on a medication that helps me not kill myself. Unfortunately it made me gain all this weight. It was either this or I'd be dead, so. . . " I don't think that would go over well with most people LOL

WRITING.TITLE: Lack of Support is Killing Me
WRITING.TEXT: I have no one. My family is dead. My extended family I don't really know and certainly wouldn't talk to. I apparently have no real friends. The best I do is post on Facebook that I'm struggling, that I'm being self destructive. Just hoping someone will message me, let me vent, do more than leave a sad face or "hugs." I don't know why I keep posting. It's the same thing every time and just cements the thoughts that no one cares. This lack of support is going to kill me.
Ditto. I haven't had a hug all year. Damn COVID isn't helping things, that's for sure. Hugs to everyone.

When I was young, I mean like elementary school, I turned it outward. I broke many doors by slamming them, yelled horrible things at loved one, actually choked some of my friends a few times. Then by middle school, it was turned completely inward with disordered eating, self injury, etc. I tihnk both inward and outward are "normal" BPD expressions. I actually think outward is what most people think of.

WRITING.TITLE: Care Too Much?
WRITING.TEXT: I think I care about others too much. I have to preface this by saying I don't have many in person friends. When I moved after college I never really made any. So most of my friends are on Facebook from high school, college, work, etc. Now that that's out of the way, if I see someone posting something that says they're struggling, suicidal, lonely, whatever, I'll normally go out of my way to response, message them, make sure they are okay, etc. When I post that I'm struggling, that I've self harmed, or that I don't see a reason to live, I get "hugs," "thinking about you," or the like. No messages asking if I'm okay. The rare times someone messages me and does ask if I'm okay, the moment I say I'm struggling, no details, just having a hard time, the subject gets changed. Do I care too much about other people and wrongly expect the same in return? It really messes with my head and "proves" that no one cares about me.
Don't see any

I had a therapist tell me the I "was a burden that everyone was ignoring." Yeah, I didn't take that well once I got home. I did eventually find a new therapist. I stayed with that one for a while because I believed her. I mean, that's what I already thought about myself. Take it from someone who's been there, find a new therapist.

I am on lithium for suicidality/severe depression. It has been helpful in regards to decreasing the urge to self harm and suicidal thoughts. I'm not "perfect" but I'm better than I was. It didn't do much for my anhedonia. I'm also one of the unlucky ones with many side effects so I often have to remind myself it's worth it.

I'm on 900mg/day. I've been as high as 1200 mg/day, decreased to see if side effects lessened, which they didn't but I didn't get any worse so stayed at the lower dose, which is the 900 mg I'm currently on. I've been on MANY psych meds over the years for depression. The current combo (I'm also on Viibryd) has been the best so far.
Impossible to say. There are so many options. It sounds like you trust him, which is probably most important.

Just make sure that what he's saying makes sense to you. Some have a specialty and they push that on everyone. Always do your own research, especially when it comes to side effects. Psych meds can have horrible side effects
Feel whatever you feel. You don't owe them anything

They won't let me sign up. "We understand it takes a tremendous amount of courage to reach out and ask for help, and you've taken a brave first step by visiting BetterHelp. Unfortunately, based on the answers given, we feel that online counseling with BetterHelp is not the best option for you."
I don't remember a time when I didn't think about suicide

WRITING.TITLE: Property Taxes
WRITING.TEXT: Anyone know if there is anything to make property tax less of a hit due to COVID 19/loss of income? I know we can make the 3 payments like always, but other than that? I tried to look around but didn't see anything. Not that I'm expecting, just hoping.

Everything I have is being left to the local SPCA to help take care of the animals. It's been set up for years now. You can leave things o a non-profit or something like that that does the work you would like to see done with that population.

Ring is having a sale on some of their cheaper doorbell cameras. They're $79 right now. Just beware in that they cannot be behind glass or a screen of any sort or they will not record motion. Learned the hard way.

40 minutes??? It took me over a month between taking a class, waiting for a license, buying the gun, waiting the 3 days to pick it up. That's not for concealed carry either, just to buy one. I would be scared to try to kill myself with a gun. I've known people who survived and I would not want to live like that.
Same.
I've had this happen before. It's actually been happening all weekend and I haven't been able to sleep because of it. I don't have any advice, but wanted to let you know you're not alone.

At the beginning of this depression, I was so angry I wasn't being productive. I kept buying all these books about how to stop being lazy, how to be more productive, get motivated, etc. My doctor was finally like "You're depressed. You're not lazy or unmotivated." No one had ever told me that before.

WRITING.TITLE: Figured Something Out
WRITING.TEXT: Today has been (should have been) a good day for me so far. I got to the gym even though I was exhausted. I went to Walmart and for the first time ever didn't wear long sleeves to cover up self harm scars. I have an interview for a job I applied to. What wrong? I don't have anyone to share these things with. Let me explain. I am basically alone. No family (they're dead) or close friends. Yes, I can share on Facebook, and often do, about these "achievements" but the comments seem so shallow. "Congrats" "Awesome!" Not that I don't appreciate people taking the time to write something encouraging, I do. But I no longer have anyone to share things with on a person level. It's like in school when you study your ass off for a test and you get an "A." Your parents might tell you they're proud of you, but it's a different type of proud than say a friend who didn't see you struggling to understand concepts, rereading the same information over and over again, etc. It's not that shared experience you have with your parents (unless you're in college, live in a dorm, and your roommate relates) I no longer have anyone that I share my life with. Likewise, when things are really bad, I have no one I feel comfortable bothering. No one understands on the deep level that my family did because no one is here seeing me struggle. They just hear about it. I don't know why I'm posting this. It came to mind and, well, I have no one to share it with that I thought might get it. Maybe someone out there can relate in some way.
To some of us it makes a difference. I don't care what the research says.

I doubt this will help, but I wanted to let you know I read your post and I hear you. I am not in a place mentally to respond in a helpful manner like I usually try to do. I'm just too exhausted right now. Please forgive me for the lack of advice. I just wanted you to know you're not alone.
Yes. I think "why can't that be me?" Thought that for most of my life.
This is one thing that keeps me from trying certain methods for sure.
I was cat-less for about 2 weeks before I realized I wouldn't make it much longer without one. He definitely keep me alive.

WRITING.TITLE: I don't want to live like this
WRITING.TEXT: I've been sick since March with probable COVID. I'm still short of breath, exhausted all the time, joint pain, chest pain, lack of taste, etc. I literally work and sleep. I can't keep up with housework. I can't do anything I enjoy. I can hardly take care of my cat. I keep telling people I don't want to live like this. I don't know what they think I mean but I mean I'd rather die than live like I am. This isn't living. I had severe depression before all of this and it's gotten exponentially worse. Impossible to see doctors face to face. Why couldn't I have just died?

Thanks for the reply. It's not the stress of the job per se (I'm a nurse) but just the being awake. I can't stay up for more than a few hours at a time without needing a nap. I work this weekend, but even if I didn't, I just sleep. I have no energy to do anything. I hate living like this.

No. Bills have to be paid. I live alone. All my close family is dead. I don't really know my extended family. No friends to speak of. It's just me, and my cat. No supportive system whatsoever. No one will care when I die.

It won't change that much. Work isn't the problem. It's all the physical problems I have post-COVID, mostly the shortness of breath with minimal activity, and the fatigue that leaves me basically bed bound if I'm not at work. Not to mention the headache, the chest pain, the full body itchiness, etc. I don't want to live like this. I can hardly navigate the stairs without needing to sit down. I can't do anything I used to enjoy. This isn't life.

I was never diagnosed with COVID as I never tested positive. They are sure I was a false negative so that's why I said "probable COVID" in my OP. I was hospitalized in April with double pneumonia. I was dealing (kind of) with my usual level of depression and suicidality. I'm not dealing well with this new physical limitation on top of everything else.

I was off for 4 months when I was sick/recovering with the bilateral pneumonia. I went back because I basically can't afford to not work any more. The shortness of breath is better in that I no longer feel like I"m going to pass out just walking around or walking up stairs. At least I'm able to work, though that's all I can do and even that is with the help of medication. Holidays and days of the week don't matter when you work in the medical field. Someone has to be there 24/7 and that someone is going to be you one time or another.

WRITING.TITLE: Strange Thoughts?
WRITING.TEXT: I'm what would be considered a "quiet" borderline. I definitely have thoughts/urges that would be better recognized as borderline behavior but I don't act on them. The current thoughts/urges just won't stop though. I've been thinking a lot of suicide lately. That's nothing new. But instead of just writing a note, I've been thinking of writing a note and faxing it to my doctor, or setting up an email to send automatically after I know I'd be dead. Kind of like a "fuck you, I asked you for help" Anyone else deal with thoughts like this? I have similar thoughts about self injury too.
I know what you mean. Every time someone dies, I think "Why can't that be me?"

Ditto. I adopted my cat almost a year ago now after his owners gave him up after 9 years. I could never let him experience that again. He's the only thing that keeps me alive. He's 12, so I either need a backup plan for when he dies or to get another cat. Or, well, what's the point?
Yes, on it now for the suicidality and self harm urges. I've gained a ton of weight, which really fucks with my "past" eating disorder, but I'm alive, so. . . . .
I don't think he'd tolerate another cat. LOL He's old and cranky. I do feed a stray cat outside and he even tried to get to it through the window.

I've never felt guilt/shame. The only reason I "hide" my scars is because it would not go over well at work. Otherwise, well, it's part of who I am. I obviously cover and tend to new injuries as they happen. Oh, and I usually wear long sleeves around little kids because they are just too inquisitive.

Fascinating! I love your use of the IAT. I really do think it's an underutilized evaluation tool. I'll have to come back to this and see if i can focus long enough to complete it. Medical and psych issues are a bitch.
I have to get blood taken all the time due to some health issues. I've never had anyone say anything to me, not even when I had bandages on.
Medicaid? Short term disability?

That's crazy. DO you have FMLA through your work? If the short term disability was federal, basically everyone gets denied the first time. It's a pain in the ass. Does your job have an employee assistance program you can call?
